sect2.title: Deployment Guide x86 / aarch64 Workflow
sect2.para: This section offers an overview of the steps required for the complete installation of &productnamereg; in the required mode. contains a full description of how to install and configure the system with &yast;.

step.para: Prepare the boot and installation media as described in .
Configure the target system firmware to boot the medium you chose. Refer to the documentation of your hardware vendor about how to configure the correct boot order.
Perform the installation as described in . The system needs to restart after the installation is finished.

Optional: Change the boot order of the system to directly boot from the medium to which &productname; has been installed. If the system boots from the installation medium, the first boot parameter will be to boot the installed system.
Perform the initial system configuration as described in .

sect2.title: Boot and Installation Media
sect2.para: When installing the system, the media for booting and for installing the system may be different. All combinations of supported media for booting and installing may be used. When using very recent hardware, it can be necessary to boot the installation with a newer kernel. For details, refer to .

sect3.title: Boot Media
sect3.para: Booting a computer depends on the capabilities of the hardware used and the availability of media for the respective boot parameter.

listitem.para: This is the most common possibility of booting a system. It is straightforward for most computer users, but requires a lot of interaction for every installation process. If you did not receive a DVD, get the ISO image from the &suse; home page and burn it to a DVD. The DVD also contains the data required for the basic installation.

varlistentry.term: Booting from a USB Flash Drive

listitem.para: In case your machine is not equipped with an optical drive, you can boot the installation image from a flash disk. To create a bootable flash disk, you need to copy a DVD image to the device using the dd command. The flash disk must not be mounted, all data on the device will be erased.
The ISO image also contains the data required for the basic installation.

You can only boot a computer directly from the network if this is supported by the computer's firmware or BIOS. This booting method requires a boot server that provides the needed boot images over the network. The exact protocol depends on your hardware. Commonly you need several services, such as TFTP and DHCP or PXE boot. For details, read .

sect3.title: Installation Media
sect3.para: The installation media contain all the necessary packages and meta information that is necessary to install a &productname;. These must be available to the installation system after booting for installation. Several possibilities for providing the installation media to the system are available with &productname;.

listitem.para: All necessary data is delivered on the boot media. Depending on the selected installation, a network connection or add-on media may be necessary.
All necessary data is delivered on the boot media. Depending on the selected installation, a network connection or add-on media may be necessary.

If you plan to install several systems, providing the installation media over the network makes things a lot easier. It is possible to install from many common protocols, such as NFS, HTTP, FTP, or SMB. For more information on how to run such an installation, refer to .

sect3.title: Installation on Hardware or Virtual Machine
sect3.para: &productname; is normally installed as an independent operating system. With Virtualization it is also possible to run multiple instances of &sls; on the same hardware. However, the installation of the &vmhost; is performed like a typical installation with some additional packages. The installation of virtual guests is described in .

sect3.title: Installation Target
sect3.para: Most installations are to a local hard disk. Therefore, it is necessary for the hard disk controllers to be available to the installation system. If a special controller (like a RAID controller) needs an extra kernel module, provide a kernel module update disk to the installation system.

Other installation targets may be various types of block devices that provide sufficient disk space and speed to run an operating system. This includes network block devices like iSCSI or SAN. It is also possible to install on network file systems that offer the standard Unix permissions. However, it may be problematic to boot these, because they must be supported by the initramfs before the actual system can start. Such installations can be useful when you need to start the same system in different locations or you plan to use virtualization features like domain migration.

sect2.title: Controlling the Installation
sect2.para: Control the installation in one of several ways. Boot the setup with one of the options listed in . To enable the different control methods refer to . For information about how to use each remote control method, refer to .
A brief overview of the different methods:

listitem.para: This is the method most frequently used to install &productname;. This also requires the smallest preparation effort but requires a lot of direct interaction.
You can control the installation via SSH either in text mode or use X-forwarding for a graphical installation. For details refer to .

For this installation method you need a second computer connected by a null modem cable to the computer on which to install &productname;. The installation then proceeds in text mode. For details refer to .
Use this method if you want a graphical installation without direct access to the target machine. For details refer to .
